prop.head.headtext: Removal of an Action from State Court to Federal Court

form.para.form.text: TO THE CLERK OF THE ABOVE-ENTITLED COURT:

PLEASE TAKE NOTICE that defendant [name of defendant] , by and through its undersigned attorney, with codefendant [name of codefendant] consenting and joining hereto, respectfully notices the removal of the within-described action to this honorable court pursuant to [citation to statute] , and in support thereof would show:

Longshoreman [name of longshoreman] caused to be filed in the Superior Court of [name of state] , County of [name of county] , [name of district] , an unverified “Complaint for Damages” against defendants [list of names of defendants] , and “DOES [range of defendants] .” Plaintiff's claim is now pending in said court as case number [number of case] . A true and accurate copy of plaintiff's papers served on [name of codefendant] is attached hereto as Exhibit [designation of exhibit] .

Plaintiff's case was filed on [date of filing case] . Defendant was served on [date of service 1] , and [name of codefendant] , a [type of entity] business entity, was served in [name of country] , on [date of service 2] . Defendant had no basis upon which to initiate removal because: (a) diversity of citizenship is lacking in that defendant, upon information and belief, is a joint venture between two entities, one of which at all relevant times was and is a [name of state] citizen and, upon information and belief, at all relevant times Plaintiff was and is a [name of state] citizen; and (b) no federal question exists as to the allegations asserted against Defendant. Although the allegations asserted against Defendant bring Plaintiff's claim against Defendant within the admiralty jurisdiction of the federal court, this fact alone is insufficient to permit removal. Therefore, the [number of days] -day period within which to file a notice of removal as mandated by 33 U.S.C.A. § 1446(b) was not triggered by service upon Defendant.
See Getty Oil Corp., a Div. of Texaco, Inc. v. Insurance Co. of North America, 841 F.2d 1254 (5th Cir. 1988)
[“In cases involving multiple defendants, the thirty-day period begins to run as soon as the first defendant is served provided the case is then removable.” ( Emphasis added.)] This Notice is filed timely and within [number of days] days of receipt by Defendant, the defendant first possessing a ground upon which the Notice of Removal could be filed. No “DOE” defendants are known to have been specifically named or served, and so the “DOE” defendants are disregarded for purposes of removal.

Plaintiff's claim is a civil complaint for injuries alleged to have been sustained while Plaintiff was operating a winch on board [name of codefendant] 's ship [name of ship] . Paragraph 7 of the complaint. The complaint further alleges at paragraph 8 that:

para.paratext: Defendants negligently inspected said vessel, negligently turned the vessel over to plaintiff's employer in an unsafe condition, negligently failed to provide plaintiff with a safe place to work, negligently failed to properly maintain the vessel's equipment, negligently represented to plaintiff's employer that the vessel's equipment was in proper working order, and negligently repaired subject winch cab window.

form.para.form.text: Upon the foregoing allegations of his complaint, Plaintiff has asserted against [name of codefendant] a “civil action of which the district courts have original jurisdiction founded on a claim or right arising under the Constitution, treaties or laws of the United States” (emphasis added) [28 U.S.C.A. § 1441(b)]. This is so because the Longshore and Harbor Workers' Compensation Act (“LHWCA”), 33 U.S.C.A. §§ 901 et seq., by its relevant terms states at § 905, “Exclusiveness of liability,” that:

para.paratext: In the event of injury to a person covered under this chapter caused by the negligence of a vessel, then such person, or anyone otherwise entitled to recover damages by reason thereof, may bring an action against such vessel as a third party in accordance with the provisions of section 933 of this title, and the employer shall not be liable to the vessel for such damages directly or indirectly and any agreements or warranties to the contrary shall be void. If such person was employed by the vessel to provide stevedoring services, no such action shall be permitted if the injury was caused by the negligence of persons engaged in providing stevedoring services. *** The liability of the vessel under this subsection shall not be based upon the warranty of seaworthiness or a breach thereof at the time the injury occurred. The remedy provided in this subsection shall be exclusive of all other remedies against the vessel except remedies available under this chapter.

form.para.form.text:
Plaintiff's allegations against [name of codefendant] implicate LHWCA § 905(b), which is judicially recognized as giving rise to a claim or right arising under one of the laws of the United States and thereby constituting a federal question. The Supreme Court decision of Scindia Steam Nav. Co., Ltd. v. De Los Santos, 451 U.S. 156, 101 S. Ct. 1614, 68 L. Ed. 2d 1 (1981), accepts that § 905(b) “radically changed the scheme of things” relative to a longshoreman's rights against the shipowner and created a statutory negligence action against ship interests.
Chavez v. Director, Office of Workers Compensation Programs, 961 F.2d 1409 (9th Cir. 1992), recognizes that LHWCA “was enacted for the benefit of claimants, [and is] a federal law passed for their benefit.”
961 F.2d at 1416–17, n. 1. ( Emphasis added.) Congressional history demonstrates that § 905(b) was intended to create a uniform federal law which would preempt conflicting state statutes.
Croshaw v. Koninklijke Nedlloyd, B. V. Rijswijk, 398 F. Supp. 1224 (D. Or. 1975).

A federal question such as is presented by plaintiff's complaint constitutes a proper basis for removal of a LHWCA § 905(b) action to the federal court.
See, Smith v. Anadrill, Inc., 761 F. Supp. 456 (S.D. Tex. 1991). (“ The federal district court has original jurisdiction to resolve federal statutory causes of action, such as plaintiffs' claims under the Longshore Harbor Workers [sic] Act. …”).

The fact that codefendant does not possess an independent basis itself upon which to seek removal does not frustrate [name of defendant] 's notice of removal. The entire action is removable pursuant to 28 U.S.C.A. § 1367, “Supplemental Jurisdiction,” which provides in relevant part:

para.paratext: (a) Except as [OPTIONAL: otherwise provided] , in any civil action of which the district courts have original jurisdiction, the district courts shall have supplemental jurisdiction over all other claims that are so related to claims in the action within such original jurisdiction that they form part of the same case or controversy under Article III of the United States Constitution. Such supplemental jurisdiction shall include claims that involve the joinder or intervention of additional parties.

form.para.form.text: The last sentence of § 1367(a) explicitly provides that the court's supplemental jurisdiction “shall” extend to include “additional parties,” and none of the exceptions set forth in part (c) apply in the circumstances of this case. Defendant already is party to the state court action, the allegations of plaintiff's complaint establish that the claims against Defendant are so related to those alleged against [name of codefendant] that they form part of the same case, and these same allegations of plaintiff's complaint state a cause within the district court's “original jurisdiction.”

No prohibition exists that would prevent or preclude the removal sought herein.
See Smith v. Anadrill, Inc., supra, at page 457 (“… there is no prohibition against removal in Longshore and Harbor Workers' Compensation Act …”).

A related case, Plaintiff's action against the ship's subcharterer interests, has been filed in this court as [title of case]
[number of docket] .
The only other defendant that has been served with summons and complaint has joined in this Notice of Removal, as evidenced by the Joinder of Defendant fled concurrently herewith.
Notice of the removal is being provided to the Superior Court and to Plaintiff's counsel.

WHEREFORE, defendant [name of defendant] , joined by codefendant [name of codefendant] , prays that the aforesaid action be removed from the state Superior Court to this court, and that the case proceed in this court as a properly removed case.

para.paratext:
The removal statutes are contained in 28 U.S.C.A. §§ 1441 to 1452, where the procedure for removal of an action from state to federal court is set out in full. The right to remove cases is entirely statutory, and must be invoked in the mode and manner prescribed.
28 U.S.C.A. § 1441(b) provides that removal may be based upon a federal question or diversity of citizenship. The amount in controversy necessary to trigger a diversity action is $75,000.00.
28 U.S.C.A. § 1332(a). No jurisdictional amount is required in federal question or admiralty cases.
28 U.S.C.A. §§ 1331 and 1333, respectively. The 2011 amendment of 28 U.S.C. sec. 1441 allows removal of actions filed under "saving to suitors” clause of 28 U.S.C. sec. 1333.
Ryan v. Hercules Offshore, Inc., 945 F. Supp. 2d 772 (S.D. Tex. 2013) (rejected by, Cassidy v. Murray, 34 F. Supp. 3d 579 (D. Md. 2014)) and (rejected by, Boudreaux v. Global Offshore Resources, LLC, 2015 WL 419002 (W.D. La. 2015)) and (rejected by, Gonzalez v. Red Hook Container Terminal LLC, 2017 A.M.C. 399, 2016 WL 7322335 (E.D. N.Y. 2016)). In personam claims filed in state court under “savings to suitors” clause remain nonmovable absent an independent basis of federal jurisdiction despite 2011 amendment of 28 U.S.C.A. 1441(b).
Mitev v. Resort Sports Limited, 133 F. Supp. 3d 1365 (S.D. Fla. 2015) (majority view). See Atlantic Coast Marine Group, Inc. v. Willis, 210 F. Supp. 3d 807 (E.D. N.C. 2016).

Cannot avoid removal by failing to plead necessary federal question—Federal Maritime Lien Act under which bank held vessel.
Rhodes v. White Lightning Sportfisherman, Inc., 2019 A.M.C. 559, 2018 WL 8188247 (E.D. N.C. 2018).

No removal under 2011 amendment of 28 U.S.C. 1441.
In re Foss Maritime Co., 29 F. Supp. 3d 955 (W.D. Ky. 2014).

An admiralty or maritime claim, although assertable in federal court in admiralty pursuant to 28 U.S.C.A. § 1333, is not per se a “suit arising” within the meaning of 28 U.S.C.A. § 1331 or 28 U.S.C.A. § 1441.
Romero v. International Terminal Operating Co., 358 U.S. 354, 79 S. Ct. 468, 3 L. Ed. 2d 368 (1959). A defendant cannot remove a case based on admiralty or maritime jurisdiction alone. An independent basis for the court's “arising under” jurisdiction, or complete diversity, must be established.
Zoila-Ortega v. B J-Titan Services Co., 751 F. Supp. 633 (E.D. La. 1990). Admiralty, unless a specific statute is involved as a possible exception, embraces a class of litigation wholly separate and distinct from those cases commonly described as presenting a “federal question,” and so are, without more, not removable as “federal question” cases.
Becker v. Crounse Corp., 822 F. Supp. 386 (W.D. Ky. 1993).
See also: Bulen v. Hall-Houston Oil Co., 953 F. Supp. 141 (E.D. La. 1997) (OCSLA).
Cornelio v. Premier Pacific Seafoods, Inc., 279 F. Supp. 2d 1228 (W.D. Wash. 2003) (wage claim); Auerbach v. Tow Boat U.S., 303 F. Supp. 2d 538 (D.N.J. 2004) (salvage service not provided—remanded) but cf. if salvage award is sought. The “principal purpose” of the grant of original federal question jurisdiction was “to afford plaintiffs a sympathetic and knowledgeable forum for the vindication of their federal rights[.]” as distinct from those rights conferred by the state, as to which state courts presumably are equally sympathetic and knowledgeable as would be a federal court.
Hunter v. United Van Lines, 746 F.2d 635, 40 Fed. R. Serv. 2d 581 (9th Cir. 1984). While the Constitution confers admiralty subject-matter jurisdiction on federal courts, a case in admiralty per se does not arise under the Constitution or the laws of the United States.
R.M.S. Titanic, Inc. v. Haver, 171 F.3d 943 (4th Cir. 1999). Saving to Suitors clause preserves common law remedies but does not bar proper removal.
EEX Corp. v. ABB Vetco Gray, Inc., 161 F. Supp. 2d 747 (S.D. Tex. 2001).Saving to suitors clause permits state procedural rules to apply and, if not inconsistent with substantive federal maritime law, the remedy may be supplemented by state law.
Kunkel v. Motor Sport, Inc., 349 F. Supp. 2d 198 (D.P.R. 2004).
See also: Offshore Logistics, Inc. v. Tallentire, 477 U.S. 207, 106 S. Ct. 2485, 91 L. Ed. 2d 174 (1986). The removal statute historically has been construed strictly against removal. For example, a third party defendant pursuant to Fed. R. Civ. P. 14(c) is not a “defendant” for removal purposes, and so lacks the capacity to remove.
Knight v. Hellenic Lines, Ltd., 543 F. Supp. 915 (E.D. N.Y. 1982). Removal not permitted on basis of a federal law defense but is allowed where well pleaded complaint establishes that claim is either created by federal law or necessarily depends upon resolution of a substantive question of federal law, even if the claim is recognized under state law.
Offshore Service Vessels, L.L.C. v. Surf Subsea, Inc., 2013 A.M.C. 247, 2012 WL 5183557 (E.D. La. 2012), also published at, 2013 A.M.C. 354 (E.D. La. 2012) (necessary to apply federal vessel documentation and coastwise trade law to reach merits of the claim). “Well pled complaint” doctrine.
Venable v. Louisiana Workers' Compensation Corp., 740 F.3d 937 (5th Cir. 2013).

Removal of statutory maritime actions may be possible, unless the statute by its terms precludes removal, upon an argument of federal question. A case arises under the Constitution, treaties or laws of the United States if it involves a claim premised upon federal law. The court will examine the allegations of a “well pleaded” complaint. Plaintiff's characterization of his claim is not conclusive, and he need not specifically cite the federal statute relied upon. However, defenses premised upon federal statutes do not qualify as a jurisdictional source.
Modern Office System, Inc. v. AIM Caribbean Exp., Inc., 802 F. Supp. 617 (D.P.R. 1992). Because claims arising under the Federal Employers Liability Act (45 U.S.C.A. §§ 51 to 60) are rendered nonremovable by 28 U.S.C.A. § 1445(a), seamen's actions under the Jones Act (46 U.S.C.A. § 688(a)) generally are nonremovable.
Pate v. Standard Dredging Corp., 193 F.2d 498 (5th Cir. 1952); Kattelman v. Otis Engineering Corp., 701 F. Supp. 560 (E.D. La. 1988). Some recent authority exists for the proposition that if a seaman waives timely objection to removal, the federal court can retain the Jones Act claim because it would have had original jurisdiction.
Johnson v. Odeco Oil and Gas Co., 864 F.2d 40 (5th Cir. 1989). Otherwise, additional claims pendent to a Jones Act claim are deemed nonremovable.
Gonsalves v. Amoco Shipping Co., 733 F.2d 1020 (2d Cir. 1984) (maintenance and cure). Remand ordered as neither admiralty nor DOHSA provided basis for removal where state law remedies are pled under "saving to suitors."
Speranza v. Leonard, 925 F. Supp. 2d 266 (D. Conn. 2013).

Removal requires an independent basis.
Cassidy v. Murray, 34 F. Supp. 3d 579 (D. Md. 2014); Removal improper under Class Action Fairness Act.
Scimone v. Carnival Corp., 720 F.3d 876 (11th Cir. 2013). Federal statutes upon which removal may be possible include the Harter Act (46 U.S.C.A. §§ 190 et seq.) and the Carriage of Goods by Sea Act.
46 U.S.C.A. §§ 1300 et seq. See Modern Office System, Inc. v. AIM Caribbean Exp., Inc., 802 F. Supp. 617 (D.P.R. 1992). COGSA has been allowed as a basis for removal to federal court.
Action Corp. v. Zim-American Israeli Shipping Co., Inc., 1992 A.M.C. 2051, 1992 WL 227001 (D.P.R. 1992).
Standard Mutiwall Bag Mfg. Co. v. Marine Terminals Corp., 961 F. Supp. 240 (D. Or. 1996); Joe Boxer Corp. v. Fritz Transp. Intern., 33 F. Supp. 2d 851 (C.D. Cal. 1998) (COGSA provides “complete preemption,” resulting in federal question jurisdiction, but in circumstances of the case, COGSA did not apply—U.S. part merely a transshipment point in carriage from China to Guatemala). COGSA claim “governed by federal law …” Abreu v. Family Shipping & Serv., 2000 WL 516565 (E.D. N.Y. 2000). However, see case where costs of remand were awarded against “experienced maritime firm” which removed a COGSA case despite the “well established principles of maritime law” such as “savings to suitors” clause, well-pleaded complaint rule, and lack of complete preemption by COGSA.
Greenidge v. Mundo Shipping Corp., 41 F. Supp. 2d 354 (E.D. N.Y. 1999).
Also: JVC Americas Corp. v. CSX Intermodal Inc., 292 F. Supp. 2d 586 (D.N.J. 2003) (remand); Superior Fish Co., Inc. v. Royal Globe Ins. Co., 521 F.Supp. 437 (E.D.Pa. 1981).

COGSA is a proper basis for removal because it regulates commerce; admiralty jurisdiction does not, however, of itself create federal question jurisdiction and so removed action is heard on the “law” side, without the removing defendant gaining the “friendlier” admiralty rules.
Sea-Land Service, Inc. v. J & W Import/Export, Inc., 976 F. Supp. 327 (D.N.J. 1997). Removal permitted in ocean bill of lading but non-COGSA case.
Capital Partners Intern. Ventures, Inc. v. Danzas Corp., 309 F. Supp. 2d 1138 (N.D. Cal. 2004). Cf.
Superior Fish Co., Inc. v. Royal Globe Ins. Co., 521 F. Supp. 437 (E.D. Pa. 1981) (removal cannot be premised upon COGSA).
Also, the Foreign Sovereign Immunities Act provides a basis for removal.
28 U.S.C.A. § 1441(d). Jones Act claim not removable because general maritime claims do not arise under the US Constitution for purposes of federal question or original admiralty jurisdiction.
Gregoire v. Enterprise Marine Services, LLC, 38 F. Supp. 3d 749 (E.D. La. 2014) (discussed in depth).

Although removal may involve numerous complicated issues, the practitioner should examine the complaint's allegations carefully, the plaintiff to limit the bases for removal and the defendant to determine whether any basis for removal exists.
See Simon v. M/V Lady Fortune, 645 F. Supp. 618 (M.D. La. 1986) (complaint failed to allege employment relation necessary in Jones Act case, defendant removed on basis of other alleged maritime grounds on an unstated jurisdictional basis. Complaint lacked properly asserted Jones Act “anchor” to state court but did demonstrate existence of diversity. Motion to remand denied).

A “savings to suitors” action in state court is removable if complete diversity of citizenship jurisdiction criteria are present.
Poirrier v. Nicklos Drilling Co., 648 F.2d 1063 (5th Cir. 1981) (personal injury); Luvi Trucking, Inc. v. Sea-Land Service, Inc., 650 F.2d 371 (1st Cir. 1981) (land movement of containers); D. J. McDuffie, Inc. v. Old Reliable Fire Ins. Co., 608 F.2d 145 (5th Cir. 1979) (marine insurance).

However, the “savings to suitors” clause addresses remedies rather than guaranteeing a non-federal forum. Therefore, the “savings” clause does not per se bar removal; the bar is that maritime claims, in and of themselves, do not arise under the laws of the United States.
See Walsh v. Seagull Energy Corp., 836 F. Supp. 411 (S.D. Tex. 1993).

If the action is removed, plaintiff may move to amend his complaint to allege admiralty jurisdiction pursuant to Fed. R. Civ. P. 9(h). The consequences of such an election are discussed at West's Federal Forms § 10672 (5th ed.).

Section 1441(e) does not repeal the “savings to suitors” clause. A maritime claim, absent exclusive federal admiralty jurisdiction, or a federal question, or complete diversity of citizenship, brought in a state court will not be accepted by a federal court by notice of removal.

28 U.S.C.A. § 1441(c) provides that where a federal question claim within the meaning of 28 U.S.C.A. § 1331 is removed and joined “with one or more otherwise nonremovable claims or causes of action,” the federal court, at its discretion, may determine all issues or remand “all matters in which State law predominates.”
Federal maritime law is applicable once a claim is within the court's admiralty jurisdiction or is a claim of admiralty or maritime law.
Genetics Intern. v. Cormorant Bulk Carriers, Inc., 877 F.2d 806 (9th Cir. 1989). There, the argument lies that an admiralty claim, even if not a federal question but pendent to a 1441(c) removal, should be retained within the federal court.
See also 28 U.S.C.A. § 1367 “Supplemental jurisdiction.”

The removal bond previously required in section 1446 was done away with in 1988. Section 1446(a) provides that the notice of removal is signed pursuant to Fed. R. Civ. P. 11. The sanctions available under that Rule are deemed sufficient protection to the plaintiff.
See also 28 U.S.C.A. § 1447(c).

The Notice of Removal set out in West's Federal Forms § 10691 (5th ed.), explicates numerous requirements for successful removal. Special notice should be taken of the 30-day rule (28 U.S.C.A. § 1447(c).
See also: Liebig v. DeJoy, 814 F. Supp. 1074 (M.D. Fla. 1993) (30-day period is mandatory and cannot be extended by court but because it is not jurisdictional it may be waived by the parties)) and that a jury should be requested forthwith. Section 1446(a) requires that a copy of “all process, pleadings, and orders” served upon the moving defendant(s) in the State court action be filed with the Notice of Removal.

Plaintiff's recourse, if he wishes to oppose the removal, is a motion to remand the case to the state court, made within thirty (30) days of the filing of the notice of removal.
28 U.S.C.A. § 1447(c). However, note should be taken of the fact that an order remanding the case “is not reviewable on appeal or otherwise” unless the removal was pursuant to § 1443 “Civil rights cases.”
28 U.S.C.A. § 1447(d); Hopkins v. Dolphin Titan Intern., Inc., 976 F.2d 924 (5th Cir. 1992).

Though an order remanding a case is non–appealable, an award of fees or sanctions within the order is appealable. In such a situation, the court of appeals must review de novo the propriety of the remand, i.e., whether the district court did have subject-matter jurisdiction by diversity or federal question. Even if incorrectly decided, the remand stands but the appellate order may trigger a new basis for removal within 30 days as a 28 U.S.C.A. § 1446(c) “paper from which it may first be ascertained that the case is *** removable.”
See generally: Dahl v. Rosenfeld, 316 F.3d 1074 (9th Cir. 2003); Maguire Oil Co. v. City of Houston, 143 F.3d 205 (5th Cir. 1998); Kirkbride v. Continental Cas. Co., 933 F.2d 729 (9th Cir. 1991).

In a cargo conversion case, where whether the conversion occurred “on land or at sea,” if the loss occurred at sea and so within admiralty jurisdiction, remand proper under “saving to suitors” clause, and also proper as no COGSA “federal question” basis for removal exists as “Congress has not clearly manifested an intent that COGSA completely preempt state law…. ” Greenidge v. Mundo Shipping Corp., 41 F. Supp. 2d 354 (E.D. N.Y. 1999) (citing Hemphill v. Transfresh Corp., 1998 WL 320840 (N.D. Cal. 1998), and discussing well pleaded complaint rule and artful pleading proscription re state law claims).

Citing to Romero v. International Terminal Operating Co., 358 U.S. 354, 79 S. Ct. 468, 3 L. Ed. 2d 368 (1959), held admiralty actions are not federal question issues under 28 U.S.C.A. § 1331 nor removable under first sentence of § 1441(b), but removal in violation of Romero is a waivable defect and a waivable limit upon the district court's subject-matter jurisdiction.
Joe Boxer Corp. v. Fritz Transp. Intern., 33 F. Supp. 2d 851 (C.D. Cal. 1998); Dao v. Knightsbridge Intern. Reinsurance Corp., 15 F. Supp. 2d 567 (D.N.J. 1998). If remand is not timely requested, the case may remain on the admiralty side and be subject to admiralty procedural rules.
Manrique v. Fagan, 2009 WL 700999 (S.D.Fl. 2009). Remand proper where Carmack inapplicable and no federal interest shown in intrastate shipment.
Maersk Inc. v. F & S Distributing Co. Inc., 2002 A.M.C. 394, 2001 WL 1875852 (C.D. Cal. 2001).

Pursuant to the “well pleaded complaint” rule, district court has jurisdiction to hear originally or by removal only those cases in which a well pleaded complaint demonstrates either that federal law establishes the cause of action or that the plaintiff's right to relief necessarily depends upon resolution of a substantive question of federal law. By eschewing claims arising out of federal law, plaintiff may choose to have his claim heard in state court. However, under the “artful pleading” exception, plaintiff cannot avoid frustrate removal by negligent mistaken or fraudulent failure to plead a federal question issue necessary to the remedy sought. The court must examine the complaint to see whether in actuality a federal issue is raised. If so, the omitted allegation will be deemed alleged.
Mesa v. California, 489 U.S. 121, 109 S.Ct. 959 (1989).

An exception to the well pleaded complaint doctrine is the “artful pleading” exception, which covers the situation where the plaintiff has no legitimate or viable state cause of action, as by pre-emption or by claim preclusion.

In multi-defendant cases, all defendants must join in the removal.
Saeilo Machinery (USA), Inc. v. Hirdes Freight, Ltd., 2000 A.M.C. 1009, 2000 WL 1205338 (C.D. Cal. 2000).

The joinder in by or consent of codefendants must be communicated to the court within the thirty day period, but cross-defendants and third-party defendants may not initiate the removal.
Saeilo Machinery, supra.

Removal does not waive forum selection clause.
Tokio Marine & Fire Ins. Co., Ltd. v. Nippon Express U.S.A. (Illinois), Inc., 118 F. Supp. 2d 997 (C.D. Cal. 2000).

Passenger case removed on diversity grounds. Joinder of travel agent deemed fraudulent and dismissed as allegation was nonactionable “puffing.”
Morris v. Princess Cruises, Inc., 236 F.3d 1061 (9th Cir. 2001); Clark v. National Shipping Co. of Saudi Arabia, 552 F.Supp.2d 576 (E.D.Va 2008).

Shipowner's indemnity claim against P & I club in Jones Act action does not support removal.
Alvarez v. Apollo Ship Chandlers, Inc., 2002 A.M.C. 1769, 2002 WL 31933666 (S.D. Fla. 2002).

Removal divests state court of jurisdiction until remand.
Lewis v. C.J. Langenfelder & Son, Jr., Inc., 266 Va. 513, 587 S.E.2d 697 (2003).

This is particularly so because, although admiralty is not asserted herein as a basis for removal, in fact, the matters alleged do state a claim within this court's admiralty subject-matter jurisdiction. This court would have original jurisdiction of such an action pursuant to 28 U.S.C.A. § 1333.
The district courts shall have original jurisdiction, exclusive of the courts of the States, of:
(1) Any civil case of admiralty or maritime jurisdiction, saving to suitors in all cases all other remedies to which they are otherwise entitled.

COGSA not an independent basis for federal question jurisdiction under 28 U.S.C. § 1337, citing Romero.
Villegas v. Magic Transport, Inc., 641 F. Supp. 2d 108 (D.P.R. 2009).

reference.block.topic.key.ref: West's Key Number Digest, Removal of Cases  84

para.paratext: Los Alamitos, California, Member, California, New York and Florida Bars
